title: How long does it take to finish calculus by Michael Spivak? What books would you recommend to read before calculus by Michael Spivak. How can I complete the book in the least amount of time? - Quora

response.answer_text: Spivak Calculus is not an easy book. If you are working through many/most/all of the problems as you should, it can easily take a year. I’d say 8 months is a good goal, as it’s the usually the goal of two semester course sequences that use the text, but they also tend to skip or skim some chapters, to you might have to work faster or do the same. As far as pre-requisites go, you should be strong in elementary algebra. If you got A’s in high school or college algebra 1 and 2, you should be fine to pick up this text if you’re motivated. It will be tough, but because of a lack of mathematical maturity more than lack of background knowledge. Trigonometric functions are defined well in the book, but it would probably be helpful (both for this book and otherwise) to learn about them in a trigonometry course since it will give you more practice with their use and more time to understand intuitively what they’re for. I don’t have any particular book recommendations for elementary texts, I think they all do a fine job. You could learn calculus from another text before approaching this text. I wouldn’t really recommend it unless you’ve already learned calculus before discovering this book, and you really want to go through it. If this is the case, you will have a much easier time with the book since it will mostly be review, but don’t get too cocky. There is a lot to learn from this book even after passing the standard calculus sequence, make sure you find those things and learn and practice them. Parts I, II, and V are all necessary, but III and IV can be picked apart a bit (but after the first two parts, you may not want to). If you want to go faster through the book, you just need to spend more time on it. You could probably work through it in a summer if you’re doing it full-time, but if you’re spending around 10 hours a week on it, I wouldn’t expect to do better than 8 months. The caveat is that the faster you work through a book, the more problems you should do. When you work slower, you have more time to absorb everything just from reading and reading, and thinking about it consciously and subconsciously throughout the in-between time. Working quicker means you need to force that information to stick, which means engaging more senses by thinking through and writing out solutions to as many problems as possible. If you learn it too quickly and don’t follow up with learning something that uses that knowledge as a pre-requisite, you’re much more likely to forget a good amount. In that case, or any other case where you’re interested in continuing on after this text, I highly recommend Spivak’s Calculus on Manifolds. It sounds tough, but it’s a perfect follow-up to this text and one of my personal favorites of all time. Only thing is, you should do a quick review or crash course of matrix and vector algebra since it expects that knowledge from you but doesn’t present it (well) itself.
